MHS’ Rich Williams shares this video and description for another fantastic #musicmonday

“The Mahopac High School Jazz Band had a very strong school year with numerous performances and a repertoire of 20-30 tunes. The group was preparing for several end of year performances with some new and additional selections and repertoire.

Prior to March 13th, 2020, the Jazz Band began working on a level VI program of music for one of our upcoming performances: NYSSMA level 6 major ensemble festival. We were planning to perform A Night in Tunisia, arranged by Michael Philip Mossman on that program.

None of us could have ever anticipated how our lives would change on March 13th. For our jazz band, March 10th was the last day that we got to hear each other play at the same time in real time. Since then, the students have remained committed to improving as musicians and finding ways to practice and perform.

We are very pleased and proud to be able to present this performance. We hope that you enjoy it!”

post_text: It’s not everyday that students get to actually touch a piece of history. Today at Austin Road, with special thanks to fifth grade teacher Mary Jean Cerbini, local historian Doc Bayne, and Travel Channel star Don Wildman, a link of the #GreatChain (500 yard long iron chain built for Patriot forces during the Revolutionary War to block British ships from sailing up the Hudson River to Albany) was the guest of honor at an assembly for fourth and fifth graders. Lisa DiMarzo, who brought the 100 pound knot of metal from Boscobel House and Gardens where it’s kept, told students, “History does not stand still. Visit your local museums, make history come to life. There is history in your backyard.” #MahopacWay
